name: SMR Neurofeedback (Sensorimotor Rhythm Training)
summary: A neurofeedback technique that trains patients to enhance brainwave activity in the sensorimotor rhythm range (12–15 Hz), often used to improve sleep, attention, and seizure control.
description: Sensorimotor Rhythm (SMR) Neurofeedback is a specialized form of EEG-based biofeedback. It targets brain activity in the 12–15 Hz range, typically recorded over the sensorimotor cortex. Training patients to increase SMR activity is associated with improved sleep quality, reduced hyperactivity, enhanced attention, and decreased seizure susceptibility. It has been used in ADHD, insomnia, and epilepsy treatment, supported by decades of clinical application.

contraindications: Severe intellectual disability (difficulty engaging in training)
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe and well-tolerated. Mild fatigue or frustration during sessions possible.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate to strong for ADHD and epilepsy; growing evidence for insomnia.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Several randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses support efficacy for ADHD and seizure reduction.

sections.text: SMR neurofeedback trains patients to increase EEG activity in the 12–15 Hz range over the sensorimotor cortex. This rhythm is associated with motor inhibition and calm, focused states. Reinforcing SMR production through operant conditioning can improve sleep, reduce hyperactivity, and lower seizure susceptibility.

sections.preparation: EEG electrodes placed over central scalp regions (C3, C4, Cz).
procedure: Baseline EEG recorded and target SMR band set.
Patients engage in training tasks (games, visual/auditory feedback) where rewards are given for sustaining SMR activity.
Training repeated across sessions to reinforce brainwave regulation.

sections.treatment_phase: Patient engages with feedback tasks designed to encourage SMR production.
sections.post_session: Data reviewed and trends monitored for progress.
sections.home_practice: No direct home practice; adherence to sessions required.

long_term: Sustained improvements in attention, seizure control, and sleep regulation

special_considerations: Motivation and engagement critical for success

ideal_candidates: Children or adults with ADHD seeking non-drug therapy
Patients with epilepsy resistant to medication

studies: Meta-analyses show moderate-to-large effects for ADHD symptom reduction.
Clinical trials demonstrate seizure reduction in epilepsy patients after SMR training.
Emerging evidence supports improved sleep in insomnia.
sections.limitations: Training requires many sessions; effects may vary by individual.

sections.pediatric: Effective for ADHD and epilepsy; commonly used in children.
sections.elderly: Can be used for insomnia and seizure management; adherence may be challenging.
sections.pregnancy: Safe and non-invasive alternative to pharmacotherapy.
sections.comorbidities: Helpful in ADHD with sleep disorders or epilepsy.

items: SMR neurofeedback is one of the oldest and most studied neurofeedback protocols.
Training effects may generalize to improved self-regulation and reduced impulsivity.
Adherence and number of sessions are key predictors of outcome.
